thread.title: Retail sales flatline as wet weather dampens demand | Business News | Sky News
thread.title_full: Retail sales flatline as wet weather dampens demand | Business News | Sky News

author: Sky UK Limited
title: Retail sales flatline as wet weather dampens demand | Business News | Sky News
text: Retail sales flatline as wet weather dampens demand Online spending was up last month as heavy rainfall put off many shoppers from heading to the high street. Friday 22 March 2024 07:39, UK Retail sales flatlined in February as "extremely" wet weather put off shoppers from heading to the high street. There was 0% growth in the sector last month, according to new figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) on Friday. It said a good performance for clothes shops and department stores was offset by falls in food and fuel sales, possibly because of rising prices at the pumps. [Money latest - Where property prices are going up and where they're falling](https://news.sky.com/story/inflation-latest-interest-rates-mortgage-money-blog-sky-news-live-13040934) However, it appears the weather also had a major impact as consumers also shunned in-person stores in favour of online shopping. February was [one of the wettest](https://news.sky.com/story/uk-weather-february-was-warmest-since-records-began-in-england-and-wales-13084406) since records began, with the south of England experiencing more than twice the level of average rainfall. Read more from business: [New Brexit border post could be demolished](https://news.sky.com/story/portsmouths-new-brexit-border-post-could-be-demolished-without-ever-being-used-13099358) [Bank of England keeps interest rate at 5.25%](https://news.sky.com/story/bank-of-england-keeps-interest-rate-at-5-25-but-cut-moves-closer-13098984) [US justice department sues Apple](https://news.sky.com/story/apple-has-kept-an-illegal-monopoly-over-smartphones-us-justice-department-claims-in-lawsuit-13099281) [ ](/download-app) Be the first to get Breaking News Install the Sky News app for free Heather Bovill, deputy director for surveys and economic indicators at the ONS, said: "Many shops told us that an extremely wet February reduced in-store sales. "But, with people staying indoors, we saw a boost of 2.1% in the amount spent online." The figure was better than the -0.3% growth predicted by economists in a Reuters poll. It comes following a [surprise increase in retail sales](https://news.sky.com/story/surprise-surge-in-retail-sales-suggests-economy-is-growing-despite-uk-entering-recession-13072731) in January.
